Senegal has said it seeks to develop its offshore blocks that have proved lucrative for oil explorers, although Cairn said it had yet to gain approval from the relevant local government authorities.

The company is looking to recover about $400 million in investment it says was promised to it by the country's government before a 2008 sale was agreed.

Cairn said in November it was seeking arbitration against the government's decision to tax the company's holdings through an indirect tax.

Cytherissa lacustris, a species of creature called ostracods, only grow to about a millimetre in length. Until now, the only way to tell them apart was by their spines.

Now scientists at Ohio State University have taken a big step towards solving the mystery of ostracod spines by building a robot that can take the same spines out on the field and replace them with a real ostracod larva.

The robot's job was to find out if the real thing looks like the tiny animal on the lab plate, and if it does it would take that larvae back to the lab and study them.

The robot is "an important contribution to understanding the biology, evolution, and behaviour" of ostracods, said researcher and lead scientist Prof Christopher C. E. Smith, of Ohio State University's Department of Biological Sciences.

The government says the dam will provide the country with much-needed power generation and improve local irrigation, but critics complain that thousands of years of cultural heritage will be lost. Beyond architecture, Hasankeyf has a rich ethnic heritage.

Pressure has grown on the UK to take more of the people fleeing to Europe from Syria after the bodies of Greece-bound migrants, including a toddler, were found in a vehicle near Austria on Wednesday.

The five men and four women were in a green Mercedes car near the border with Germany. Austria's interior ministry said they were believed to be Syrian refugees, but police said there were no papers to back up that assertion.

German police found the bodies of the Syrians after making a routine check at the border crossing into Austria from Hungary late on Wednesday morning.

The vehicle had been discovered in a "deadlock", where the vehicles of those arriving in Austria at the border with Slovenia have to wait until the border with Germany is opened.

The UK's Home Office says it is unable to comment on how many people are crossing the border from Syria, and so cannot respond to claims by charities about their own figures.

raw_results.original: Beneath the carpet is a mesh of optical fibres that detect and plot movement as pressure bends them, changing the light detected at the carpet's edges. These deflected light patterns help electronics "learn" walking patterns and detect if they are deteriorating, for instance in the elderly. The carpet was demonstrated at the Photon12 conference in Durham, UK. The optical fibre network at the heart of the effort makes use of the same types of fibres that transmit data to homes and across oceans, in which light bounces along the fibres' length. To make them sensitive to the deflection caused by pressure, the researchers carved grooves in the fibres along their length so that the bouncing of the light was less efficient at the point where pressure was applied. Detectors at the carpet's edge convert the light into electrical signals which are then analysed by a computer. That analysis borrows heavily from technology developed at the university for use with medical scanners.
